questions.text: A 27-year-old nulligravid woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of fertility. She has been unable to conceive for 1 year despite regular intercourse with her husband twice per week. Recent analysis of her husband's semen showed a normal sperm count. Two years ago, she had an episode of a febrile illness with lower abdominal pain, which resolved under treatment with a medication she cannot recall. Menarche occurred at the age of 12 years, and menses occur at regular 28-day intervals and last 4 to 5 days. Before her marriage, she was sexually active with 4 male partners and used a combined oral contraceptive pill with estrogen and progesterone consistently, in addition to barrier protection inconsistently. One year ago, she stopped using the oral contraceptive pill to try and conceive. She is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 84 kg (185 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m2. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's infertility?

choices.text: Long-term use of the oral contraceptive pill

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) may present with failure to conceive due to absent or infrequent ovulation. Key features of PCOS include hyperandrogenism, ovulatory dysfunction (i.e., amenorrhea or oligomenorrhea), and obesity. Although this patient is obese (BMI 31 kg/m2), she has regular menstrual cycles and no clinical features of hyperandrogenism, such as hirsutism or acne. Therefore, it is unlikely that she has PCOS.

B) INCORRECT:

Long-term use of the oral contraceptive pill has no effect on fertility. Studies have shown that pregnancy rates following cessation of oral contraceptives, contraceptive implants, monthly contraceptive injections, copper intrauterine devices, and/or levonorgestrel intrauterine systems are similar to those reported following discontinuation of barrier methods or use of no contraceptive method.

C) INCORRECT:

Endometriosis, resulting in pelvic inflammation and uterine adhesions, is one of the most common causes of infertility in women between 20–40 years of age. However, endometriosis commonly manifests with dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, postcoital bleeding, nonspecific abdominal or pelvic pain, and is rarely asymptomatic. This patient does not have any of the clinical features associated with endometriosis, making it an unlikely cause of her infertility.

D) INCORRECT:

Primary ovarian insufficiency (POI) commonly manifests with amenorrhea or irregular menstrual cycles. This condition can also manifest with symptoms of menopause, such as vaginal dryness, hot flashes, or mood disturbances. This patient has regular menstrual cycles and does not have any symptoms of menopause, making POI an unlikely cause of her infertility.

E) CORRECT:

Infertility following PID is a result of tubal scarring (due to salpingitis) with consequent loss of ciliary action and tubal occlusion. The risk of infertility increases with the number of episodes of PID and is around 12%, 25%, and 50% after one, two, and three episodes of PID, respectively. This patient needs further testing (e.g., hysterosalpingogram) for the evaluation of her fallopian tubes and the degree of damage. She may also require either surgery or in vitro fertilization to restore fertility.

Other complications associated with PID include tuboovarian abscess, pelvic peritonitis, sepsis, Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome, and ectopic pregnancy.
Image Description:

Hysterosalpingogram

The tube is occluded at the isthmic portion of the fallopian tubes on both sides (arrows). Size and shape of the uterine cavity are inconspicuous.

These findings are consistent with bilateral tubal blockage.

F) INCORRECT:

Cervical insufficiency (CI) is the inability of the cervix to retain a pregnancy in the second trimester in the absence of labor, contractions or any other underlying pathologies (e.g., infection, bleeding, premature rupture of membranes). While cervical insufficiency may prevent women from carrying pregnancies to term, CI does not affect a woman's ability to conceive.
questions.hint: This woman previously engaged in high-risk sexual behavior (inconsistent use of barrier protection) and had an episode of lower abdominal pain and febrile illness. This suggests an underlying diagnosis of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID).

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes to the physician because she has been unable to conceive for 3 years. Her husband's sperm count has been normal during this time. She has had episodic pelvic and back pain accompanied by painful diarrhea for 5 years. She reports having one episode per month on average, and each episode lasts 4–6 days. She takes ibuprofen for the pain, which provides some relief. Menses have occurred at regular 29-day intervals since menarche at the age of 14 years and last for 7 days. She is sexually active with her husband, and they do not use contraception. Vital signs are within normal limits. Pelvic and bimanual examinations are normal. There is mild rectovaginal tenderness on digital rectal examination. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Activation of lymphatic cells and tissue damage in the intestinal walls
Loss of fallopian tube function following infection
Smooth muscle tumor arising from the myometrium
Endometrial tissue outside the uterine cavity
Increased secretion of androgens and luteinizing hormone

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Activation of lymphatic cells in the intestinal walls is the underlying pathophysiology of Crohn disease, which manifests with episodic diarrhea. However, Crohn disease also manifests with other gastrointestinal symptoms such as right lower quadrant abdominal pain and/or a palpable mass, and constitutional symptoms, which are not seen in this patient. In addition, Crohn disease is not typically associated with infertility.

B) INCORRECT:

Loss of fallopian tube function following infection is the mechanism of infertility in chronic pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) due to a sexually transmitted infection (most commonly gonorrhea or chlamydia). PID can have a subclinical course, manifesting with subtle features such as pelvic pain rather than overt symptoms of PID (e.g., vaginal discharge, fever). However, the monthly recurring pattern of diarrhea and pelvic pain makes another cause of infertility more likely in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Uterine leiomyomas are the most common tumor of the female genital tract and can cause back and/or pelvic pain and reproductive abnormalities such as infertility. Predisposing factors include nulliparity and age 25–45 years. While leiomyomas can cause bowel symptoms (e.g., constipation), they are usually not associated with diarrhea. Symptomatic leiomyomas manifest with abnormal menstruation (e.g., heavy menstrual bleeding) and an enlarged, firm, and/or irregular uterus on bimanual pelvic examination, which are not seen in this patient.

D) CORRECT:

Endometrial tissue outside the uterine cavity is the underlying mechanism of endometriosis. Like the endometrium within the uterine cavity, this tissue reacts to the hormone cycle by proliferating in response to estrogen. Symptoms depend on the location of the endometrial tissue and characteristically worsen before the onset of menses, emphasizing the importance of taking a menstrual history. Given this patient's recurring diarrhea and mild rectovaginal tenderness, rectovaginal endometriosis is the most likely diagnosis. Treatment options for endometriosis include NSAIDs and continuous combined hormonal contraceptives in patients not trying to conceive. Advanced treatments include estrogen-suppressing pharmacological treatment (e.g., GnRH agonists) to inhibit the growth of endometrial tissue, and surgical options (e.g., laparoscopic excision of the lesions).

Infertility in endometriosis is caused by inflammation and adhesions that can change pelvic anatomy, altering egg quality and impairing implantation. Normal findings on pelvic examination and imaging (e.g., transvaginal ultrasound, hysterosalpingography) do not rule out endometriosis. The management of infertility due to endometriosis depends on the severity and location of the disease and includes laparoscopic excision of the lesions and in vitro fertilization.

E) INCORRECT:

Increased androgen secretion and elevated luteinizing hormone are hallmarks of polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS), which is a leading cause of infertility. PCOS manifests with menstrual irregularities (e.g., primary or secondary amenorrhea, oligomenorrhea), insulin resistance and associated conditions (especially obesity), and/or skin conditions (e.g., hirsutism), which are not seen in this patient. In addition, PCOS is not associated with pelvic pain or diarrhea.

F) INCORRECT:

Primary ovarian insufficiency (POI) causes infertility. POI is associated with abnormal menstrual bleeding and climacteric symptoms (e.g., vaginal dryness, night sweats, hot flashes), which are not seen in this patient. In addition, pelvic pain and diarrhea are not features of POI.
questions.hint: This patient's monthly episodes of back and pelvic pain and diarrhea are most likely related to her menstrual cycle.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman comes to the physician because she has been unable to conceive for 3 years. She and her partner are sexually active and do not use contraception. They were partially assessed 6 months ago. Analysis of her husband's semen showed normal sperm counts, and hormonal assays for both partners were normal. Her menses occur at regular 28-day intervals and last 5 to 6 days. Her last menstrual period was 2 weeks ago. She had a single episode of urinary tract infection 4 years ago and was treated with oral antibiotics. Vaginal examination shows no abnormalities. Bimanual examination shows a normal-sized uterus and no palpable adnexal masses. Rectal examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Psychological counseling is recommended for all couples who seek evaluation for infertility because not being able to conceive is associated with emotional stress and can lead to depression, anxiety, and feelings of worthlessness. Moreover, emotional stress may decrease libido. While this couple should receive psychological counseling, further evaluation for the cause of infertility is also necessary.

B) INCORRECT:

A postcoital test was used in the past but is no longer recommended since the results are a poor predictor of the ability to conceive and do not affect clinical management of infertility in any way.

C) INCORRECT:

Hysteroscopy is the most appropriate next step in the diagnostic evaluation of the female partner if she has risk factors for tubal obstruction, such as endometriosis, pelvic inflammatory disease, or a previous ectopic pregnancy. This patient does not have a history suggestive of any of these conditions. Hysteroscopy is therefore not indicated at this point.

D) CORRECT:

If the initial workup does not reveal any abnormalities and the patient has no history suggestive of tubal obstruction, the most appropriate next step in the evaluation of infertility is hysterosalpingography (HSG) or sonohysterosalpingography to screen for tubal occlusion and structural uterine abnormalities (e.g., septate uterus, submucous fibroids, intrauterine adhesions). In some cases, HSG can also be therapeutic because it can remove small adhesions or mucous plugs obstructing the tubal lumen. If evidence of intrauterine abnormalities or tubal occlusion is seen on HSG, hysteroscopy and/or laparoscopy should be performed next.
Image Description:

Hysterosalpingogram

The tube is occluded at the isthmic portion of the fallopian tubes on both sides (arrows). Size and shape of the uterine cavity are inconspicuous.

These findings are consistent with bilateral tubal blockage.

E) INCORRECT:

Karyotyping for chromosomal defects such as Klinefelter syndrome or Y chromosomal deletions should be performed on the male partner if semen analysis shows oligo-/azoospermia and there is evidence of hypergonadotropic hypogonadism on hormonal analysis. This patient's partner has a normal semen analysis and normal levels of testosterone. Karyotyping is also conducted if Turner syndrome is suspected, but this female patient has no signs to indicate this condition (e.g., typical physical features, amenorrhea). Karyotyping is therefore not necessary.

F) INCORRECT:

Endometrial biopsy should be performed during the evaluation of infertility only if abnormal uterine bleeding or a history suggestive of chronic endometritis is present. This patient has regular menstrual cycles and no history of lower abdominal pain, fever, or vaginal discharge to suggest chronic endometritis. Endometrial biopsy is therefore not indicated at this point.
questions.hint: An inability to conceive after one year of regular unprotected intercourse in a woman < 35 years of age indicates infertility. This couple's preliminary assessment revealed no male factor and no hormonal disturbances.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman comes to the physician because she has been unable to conceive for more than a year. Conception by in vitro fertilization (IVF) was attempted once 3 months ago but was unsuccessful. Analysis of her husband's semen has shown normal sperm counts and morphology. She has a 6-year-old daughter who was born at term after an uncomplicated pregnancy. She has no history of severe illness and tries to stay healthy by going to the gym for one hour every day. Her menses occur at regular 28-day intervals and last 5 to 6 days; her last menstrual period started 2 days ago. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's inability to conceive?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Polycystic ovarian syndrome also causes infertility, but this patient lacks any other typical symptoms of this condition, such as menstrual irregularities, hirsutism, obesity, and acne.

B) INCORRECT:

Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) is one of the most common causes of female infertility and is due to adhesions of the fallopian tubes and ovaries following infection of the reproductive tract. This patient has no history of sexually transmitted infections or episodes suggestive of PID (e.g., lower abdominal pain, dysuria, purulent vaginal discharge, fever), making this an unlikely cause.

C) INCORRECT:

Asherman syndrome is characterized by endometrial adhesions and/or fibrosis mostly caused by dilation and curettage. Since this patient has no history of uterine surgery, this diagnosis is extremely unlikely. In addition, the flow and duration of menstrual bleeds are often reduced in Asherman syndrome, which is not the case in this patient.

D) CORRECT:

Diminished ovarian reserve (DOR), which is a common cause of infertility in women of advanced maternal age (≥ 35 years), is characterized by a decline in the number of functioning oocytes. DOR is a normal part of aging, although it can also be the result of an underlying disease or injury to the ovaries (e.g., radiation therapy). Women with DOR usually have a poor response to ovarian stimulation during IVF (i.e., retrieval of ≤ 3 oocytes) and lower implantation rates. If IVF using the patient's own oocytes fails, oocyte donation is a treatment option with high success rates.

DOR, which is physiological, needs to be distinguished from primary ovarian insufficiency, a disorder characterized by a cessation of ovarian function before the age of 40.

E) INCORRECT:

Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism can be primary or secondary, with the secondary variant being far more common. Causes include brain tumors, head trauma but also intense exercise. However, hypogonadotropic hypogonadism would be accompanied by amenorrhea.

F) INCORRECT:

Primary ovarian insufficiency (POI), which causes infertility, is characterized by a cessation of ovarian function before the age of 40. However, POI also manifests with symptoms of menopause, such as irregular menstrual cycle or amenorrhea, hot flashes, and vaginal dryness, which are not seen here.
questions.hint: This 35-year-old woman has no symptoms, no history of severe illness, regular menses, and a normal physical examination.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 1, comes to the physician because she has been unable to conceive for the past year. During this time, she has not had a menstrual period. She also reports episodic pelvic pain that occurs every 4 weeks and lasts for several days. Menses previously occurred at regular 28-day intervals. She is sexually active with her husband and does not use contraceptives. Her child was born at term after vaginal delivery 14 months ago. The postpartum course was complicated by hemorrhage from retained placental products, for which the patient underwent uterine curettage. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Speculum examination shows a normal vagina and cervix. The uterus is normal in size, and no adnexal masses are palpated. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Midcycle serum studies show:


Thyroid-stimulating hormone
3.9 μU/mL


Follicle-stimulating hormone
54 mIU/mL


Luteinizing hormone
110 mIU/mL


Prolactin
15 ng/mL


β-hCG
negative


Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?

choices.text: Measurement of midluteal serum progesterone concentration

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Measurement of midluteal serum progesterone levels is used to assess ovulatory function in patients with a history of infertility and secondary amenorrhea. Anovulation can be caused by primary hypogonadism (e.g., polycystic ovary syndrome, primary ovarian insufficiency) or secondary hypogonadism (e.g., hyperprolactinemia due to prolactinoma). In this patient with normal serum hormone studies, amenorrhea and infertility are unlikely to be caused by anovulation.

B) INCORRECT:

Diagnostic laparoscopy is a confirmatory test for endometriosis, which can manifest with cyclic pelvic pain and infertility. However, this patient has amenorrhea, which is not a feature of endometriosis. In addition, physical examination in endometriosis typically shows rectovaginal tenderness, adnexal masses, and lateral displacement of the cervix, none of which are present in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

MRI of the brain is the preferred imaging modality to confirm Sheehan syndrome (SS). SS is caused by ischemia and necrosis of the pituitary gland due to severe postpartum hemorrhage. Patients with SS typically have LH and FSH deficiency. Although SS also manifests with secondary amenorrhea and infertility, this patient has normal levels of LH and FSH, making SS unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

Thyroid antibody testing is used to confirm suspected autoimmune thyroiditis, such as Hashimoto disease, which is the most common cause of hypothyroidism in the US. Overt hypothyroidism may result in amenorrhea and subsequent infertility. However, a compensatory increase in thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) levels is expected, whereas this patient's TSH is within the reference range.

E) CORRECT:

Hysteroscopy is a confirmatory test for intrauterine adhesions, also known as Asherman syndrome (AS). AS most commonly occurs following intrauterine instrumentation (e.g., dilation and curettage) and may manifest with infertility, secondary amenorrhea, and cyclic pelvic pain (due to blood accumulation in the uterus). Serum concentrations of FSH, LH, and prolactin are typically within the reference ranges. AS is usually asymptomatic; the standard treatment for symptomatic AS is hysteroscopic resection of the adhesions.

The workup of secondary amenorrhea includes a progestin and/or an estrogen/progestin withdrawal test, which induces withdrawal bleeding in patients with anovulatory cycles (e.g., due to polycystic ovary syndrome, primary ovarian insufficiency). Because of the presence of intrauterine adhesions and blocked outflow tract, these tests do not cause bleeding in patients with AS.
questions.hint: This patient's infertility and secondary amenorrhea most likely developed as a complication of uterine curettage.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man comes to the physician with his wife because they have been unable to conceive. They have had regular unprotected sex for the past 18 months without using contraception. His wife has been tested and is fertile. The patient began puberty at the age of 13 years. He has been healthy except for infection with Chlamydia trachomatis 10 years ago, which was treated with azithromycin. He is a professional cyclist and trains every day for 3–4 hours. His wife reports that her husband has often been stressed since he started to prepare for the national championships a year ago and is very conscious about his diet. His temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 50/min, and blood pressure is 154/92 mm Hg. Physical examination of the husband shows an athletic stature with uniform inflammatory papular eruptions of the face, back, and chest. Genital examination shows small testes. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's infertility?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cushing syndrome is a known risk factor for infertility. Hypercortisolism inhibits the release of gonadotropin-releasing hormone, which in turn results in reduced spermatogenesis. Reduced libido and erectile dysfunction can also occur. This diagnosis can generally be ruled out based on clinical features. While this patient's acne and hypertension are features of Cushing syndrome, other features such as muscle weakness, thinning of the skin, central obesity, sleep disturbances, and reduced libido would also be present.

B) CORRECT:

Anabolic steroids are the performance-enhancing drugs most commonly used by athletes to improve muscle mass and strength. Chronic anabolic steroid use can result in secondary hypogonadism due to the negative feedback of androgens on the hypothalamic-pituitary axis (↓ LH, ↓ FSH). This can lead to reduced spermatogenesis and abnormal sperm motility, causing infertility. Small testes, as seen in this patient, are a common finding. Uniform papular eruptions (steroid acne), hypertension, and the very muscular physique of this patient also indicate anabolic steroid use. A low sperm count would support the diagnosis.

Sperm count and testicular size typically return to normal a few months after discontinuation of anabolic steroids, although azoospermia may persist for several years.

C) INCORRECT:

Scrotal hyperthermia is a weak risk factor for infertility that acts by reducing spermatogenesis and resulting in reduced sperm viability. Cycling training requiring long periods on a bicycle saddle can cause prolonged periods of heat due to friction in the genital area, which could be a contributing factor to this patient's infertility. However, this does not account for the patient's small testes, hypertension, and acne. Other causes of scrotal hyperthermia include varicocele and the use of laptop computers on the lap.

D) INCORRECT:

Primary hypertension can cause erectile dysfunction, which affects the ability to conceive. Arterial hypertension is a very unlikely diagnosis in a young, athletic patient. On the contrary, it is generally associated with advanced age, a history of smoking, and physical inactivity. This patient's hypertension is much more likely to be secondary to the same cause as his infertility.

E) INCORRECT:

Chlamydia infection, one of the most common sexually transmitted infections in the US, can result in infertility. Particularly asymptomatic infections that go undetected can result in obstruction of the ductus deferens and subsequent azoospermia. While this patient has a history of chlamydia infection, it is unlikely to be the underlying cause of his infertility because his infection was treated appropriately. In addition, it would not explain the patient's small testes, hypertension, and acne.

F) INCORRECT:

Infertility due to secondary hypogonadism is a known complication of anorexia nervosa. High pressure sport careers are associated with an increased incidence of anorexia, and although the patient exhibits signs of restrictive eating and excessive exercise, this is not sufficient to suspect anorexia nervosa. Patients typically present with signs of starvation and malnutrition, such as hypothermia, dry skin, hair loss, muscle wasting, bradycardia, hypotension, and electrolyte disturbances. Furthermore, the condition is also much more common in women than in men.

G) INCORRECT:

Erectile dysfunction is the most common sexual disorder in men. Although it is most commonly secondary to an organic cause (e.g., diabetic neuropathy, antidepressants, trauma), it can also be psychogenic, occurring secondary to depression, anxiety (performance-related), relationship issues, and stress. The couple report that they have regular intercourse, making this diagnosis unlikely. In addition, it would not explain the patient's small testes, hypertension, and acne.

H) INCORRECT:

Kallmann syndrome is a rare, genetic form of infertility due to hypogonadotropic hypogonadism. It is more common in men and presentation varies according to the underlying mutation. Classic signs in male patients include absent puberty or delayed, partial puberty with reduced muscle mass, small stature, small testes, and absent or scarce body hair growth. Anosmia would also be expected. Although this patient has small testes, no other characteristic signs are present.
questions.hint: This patient's infertility is most likely related to his career as a professional cyclist.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of infertility. She has been unable to conceive for the past 2 years. Menses occur at 45 to 80-day intervals. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 77 kg (170 lb); BMI is 27 kg/m2. Physical examination shows facial acne and pigmented hair on the upper lip. Serum studies show elevated levels of testosterone and an LH:FSH ratio of 4:1. Treatment with the appropriate drug for this patient's infertility is begun. Which of the following is the primary mechanism of action of this drug?

choices.text: Activation of ovarian luteinizing hormone receptors

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Activation of pituitary dopamine receptors is the mechanism of action of bromocriptine, which is used in women who suffer from anovulatory infertility due to hyperprolactinemia. Elevated serum prolactin levels inhibit GnRH secretion, resulting in low levels of FSH and LH (hypogonadotropic hypogonadism). Patients would present with anovulation, amenorrhea, galactorrhea, and possibly symptoms of a pituitary macroadenoma (headaches, bitemporal hemianopia). Bromocriptine is not used to treat infertility caused by PCOS.

B) INCORRECT:

Inhibition of endometrial progesterone receptors is the mechanism of action of mifepristone, which is used in conjunction with a prostaglandin analog (e.g., misoprostol) for medical termination of pregnancy. It is not used to treat infertility in PCOS.

C) INCORRECT:

Activation of ovarian luteinizing hormone (LH) receptors is caused by human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) as LH and hCG have a similar molecular structure and share the same receptors. Injectable hCG causes an LH surge that stimulates ovarian follicular maturation and ovulation and is therefore used to induce ovulation in infertile women. However, it is only a second-line treatment in PCOS because of its higher costs and an increased risk of multiple pregnancy.

D) INCORRECT:

Inhibition, not activation of hypothalamic estrogen receptors, is the mechanism of action of clomiphene, a drug for ovulation induction in women with infertility from PCOS. Clomiphene is a selective estrogen receptor modulator that binds to the hypothalamic estrogen receptors, thereby blocking the negative feedback effect of circulating endogenous estradiol. This results in an increase in the pulsatile secretion of GnRH and subsequent increase in both FSH and LH, stimulating ovulation.

E) CORRECT:

Inhibition of granulosa cell aromatase is the mechanism of action of letrozole, which inhibits the conversion of androgens to estrogens and lowers estrogen levels, stimulating FSH and LH secretion and inducing ovulation. Treatment with letrozole leads to higher live birth rates than clomiphene citrate, making it the first-line treatment for individuals with PCOS who wish to conceive.
questions.hint: This patient's oligomenorrhea, clinical and laboratory signs of hyperandrogenemia (facial acne, hirsutism, elevated serum testosterone), and the LH:FSH ratio > 2:1 suggests that her infertility is due to polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS). A first-line treatment for women with PCOS pursuing pregnancy is letrozole.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of infertility. He does not smoke, drink, or take any medications. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Serum analysis shows anti-sperm antibodies. What is the most likely cause of this patient's serum finding?

choices.text: Defect in the dynein arm of cilia

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Increased scrotal temperature is seen in conditions such as varicocele and cryptorchidism. It can hinder spermatogenesis and therefore cause infertility. Varicocele classically manifests with a “bag of worms” appearance, while patients with cryptorchidism have an empty scrotum on examination. This patient's physical examination was normal, making another etiology the more likely cause of his infertility.

B) INCORRECT:

Dysgenesis of seminiferous tubules is seen in Klinefelter syndrome. Patients with this genetic condition characteristically present with a tall/slender body habitus, gynecomastia, small testes, and infertility. Although this patient presents with infertility, his normal physical examination and the presence of anti-sperm antibodies make another condition the more likely cause.

C) INCORRECT:

Bilateral dysgenesis of the vas deferens is seen in patients with cystic fibrosis (CF). This dysgenesis results in azoospermia and thus infertility, which are seen in this patient. However, patients with CF also have recurrent sinopulmonary infections, pancreatic insufficiency, and most often a family history of this disease. CF is unlikely in an otherwise healthy patient with a normal physical examination.

D) CORRECT:

A defect in Sertoli cell tight-junction proteins (claudins and occludins) can result in infertility due to impairment of the blood-testis barrier. This type of defect allows spermatozoa to enter the bloodstream, which are recognized by serum immune cells as foreign, and thus anti-sperm antibodies are created. The antibodies can lead to immobilization and agglutination of sperm or have a spermatotoxic effect.

E) INCORRECT:

Defects in the dynein arm of cilia are seen in Kartagener syndrome. This form of primary ciliary dyskinesia results in decreased sperm motility and therefore infertility. Other sequelae of Kartagener syndrome include situs inversus, chronic sinusitis, and hearing loss, which are not present in this patient.

F) INCORRECT:

GnRH deficiency is seen in Kallmann syndrome, a rare genetic disorder that can cause infertility. Patients with Kallmann syndrome also have associated developmental abnormalities (e.g., cleft lip, cryptorchidism, scoliosis, anosmia). Given that this patient's physical examination was normal and the detection of serum anti-sperm antibodies, Kallmann syndrome is unlikely to be the cause of his infertility.
questions.hint: In order for anti-sperm antibodies to develop, sperm antigens must be exposed to immune cells in the serum.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man comes to the physician because he and his wife have been unable to conceive despite regular unprotected sex for the past 15 months without using contraception. His wife has been tested and is fertile. The patient began puberty at the age of 14 years. He was treated for Chlamydia trachomatis 6 years ago. He is a professional cyclist and trains every day for 3–4 hours. He feels stressed because of an upcoming race. His blood pressure is 148/92 mm Hg. Physical examination of the husband shows a tall, athletic stature with uniform inflammatory papular eruptions of the face, back, and chest. Genital examination shows small testes. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's infertility?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Erectile dysfunction is the most common sexual disorder in men. Although it is most commonly secondary to an organic cause (e.g., diabetic neuropathy, antidepressants, trauma), it can also be psychogenic, occurring secondary to depression, anxiety (performance-related), relationship issues, and stress. The couple report that they have regular intercourse, making this diagnosis unlikely. In addition, it would not explain the patient's small testes, hypertension, and acne.

B) INCORRECT:

Kallmann syndrome is a rare, genetic form of infertility caused by decreased production of GnRH from the hypothalamus, leading to hypogonadotropic hypogonadism. It is more common in men and presentation varies according to the underlying mutation. Classic signs in male patients include absent puberty or delayed, partial puberty with reduced muscle mass, small stature, small testes, and absent or scarce body hair growth. Anosmia would also be expected. Although this patient has small testes, no other characteristic signs are present.

C) CORRECT:

Anabolic steroids are the performance-enhancing drugs most commonly used by athletes to improve muscle mass, strength, and recovery. Chronic anabolic steroid use can result in secondary hypogonadism due to the negative feedback of androgens on the hypothalamic-pituitary axis, which lowers LH and FSH levels. A lower FSH level leads to reduced spermatogenesis in Sertoli cells. Reduced LH decreases the Leydig cell production of gonadal testosterone, which is also important for spermatogenesis. Reduced testosterone results in smaller testes as well. Uniform papular eruptions (steroid acne) and hypertension in this patient further support anabolic steroid use as the cause of his infertility. A low sperm count would also be expected.

D) INCORRECT:

Chlamydia infection, one of the most common STIs in the US, can result in infertility. Particularly asymptomatic infections that go undetected/untreated can result in obstruction of the ductus deferens (azoospermia) in male patients. While this patient has a history of chlamydia infection, it is unlikely to be the underlying cause of his infertility because his infection was properly treated. In addition, it would not explain the patient's small testes, hypertension, and acne.

E) INCORRECT:

Scrotal hyperthermia is a weak risk factor for infertility that acts by reducing spermatogenesis and resulting in reduced sperm viability. Cycling training requiring long periods on a bicycle saddle can cause prolonged periods of heat due to friction in the genital area, which could be a contributing factor to this patient's infertility. However, this does not account for the patient's small testes, hypertension, and acne.

Other causes of scrotal hyperthermia include varicocele and the use of laptop computers on the lap rather than a desk or table.

F) INCORRECT:

Klinefelter syndrome is a genetic disorder due to inheritance of an additional X chromosome, usually resulting in male sterility via decreased testosterone production and spermatogenesis. Although this patient's tall stature and small testes correspond with this diagnosis, most patients do not reach full sexual maturity and have features of scarce facial/body hair, gynecomastia, and some cognitive impairments, which are not seen in this patient.
questions.hint: This patient's infertility is related to his career as a professional athlete.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-year history of infertility. She has a history of anorexia nervosa and has received dietary and behavioral therapy over the past 6 months with minimal improvement in her symptoms. She is 170 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 49 kg (104 lb); her BMI is 17 kg/m2. Physical examination shows pallor and thin, soft, depigmented hair on the arms and back. After an extensive workup, the physician recommends pulsatile GnRH therapy for infertility treatment. At a follow-up examination one week after initiating therapy, a pelvic ultrasound shows a 24-mm hypoechogenic cavity in the right ovary. The patient subsequently receives a drug that results in the resumption of meiosis and the loss of gap junctions between the cumulus granulosa cells and the oocyte. This patient most likely received which of the following drugs at the follow-up examination?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Leuprolide is a GnRH analog that can be used in infertility treatment to stimulate ovarian follicle maturation. This patient, however, has already received pulsatile GnRH to stimulate follicular maturation. Leuprolide does not induce ovulation.

B) INCORRECT:

Mifepristone is a competitive progesterone antagonist most commonly used in conjunction with a prostaglandin analog for medical termination of pregnancy. At low doses, mifepristone leads to endometrial contraction, which promotes premature detachment of the ovum and results in abortion. It would not be indicated in the treatment of infertility to induce ovulation.

C) CORRECT:

Recombinant human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG), which is structurally similar to LH, is commonly used to induce ovulation. After ovarian follicle maturation is achieved with pulsatile GnRH therapy, as seen on this patient's pelvic ultrasound, recombinant hCG can then be administered to induce ovulation as part of assisted reproductive therapy. Recombinant hCG stimulates LH receptors, mimicking the mid-cycle LH surge to stimulate final oocyte maturation and ovulation.

Endogenous hCG, which is normally produced by the placenta after implantation, is used to detect pregnancy and plays no role in ovulation.

D) INCORRECT:

Ethinyl estradiol inhibits follicular maturation and ovulation by decreasing FSH secretion through negative feedback on the pituitary gland. It would not be used for ovulation induction.

E) INCORRECT:

Synthetic medroxyprogesterone can be used in the treatment of infertility to stimulate endometrial changes necessary for successful implantation. Synthetic progesterone, however, has no effect on follicle maturation or ovulation.
questions.hint: Anorexia nervosa can cause infertility as a result of hypogonadotropic hypogonadism. Pulsatile GnRH therapy stimulates endogenous FSH secretion and ovarian follicle maturation. Resumption of meiosis and the loss of gap junctions between the oocyte in the follicle and the cumulus granulosa cells are changes that occur during ovulation.

questions.text: A 32-year-old nulligravid woman and her 34-year-old husband come to the physician because they have been unable to conceive for the past 6 months. During this time, they have had unprotected sexual intercourse four times per week. The woman has had four previous sexual partners and her husband has had one previous sexual partner. Neither partner has previously conceived a child. The woman reports having regular menses at 30-day intervals. Her last menstrual period was 3 weeks ago. The man had uncomplicated gonorrhea 10 years ago, which was treated with ceftriaxone. Both take daily vitamin supplements, but no other medications. Physical examinations of both patients show no abnormalities. Urine pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An Anti-Müllerian hormone level can be used for the diagnosis of diminished ovarian reserve (DOR) in patients with suspected infertility. This 32-year-old woman has regular menses, an unremarkable medical history, and no abnormalities on physical examination, so DOR is unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

Serum testosterone and FSH levels can be measured as a part of the infertility workup in male individuals with suspected hypogonadism. Patients with hypogonadism typically present with sexual dysfunction, gynecomastia, and testicular atrophy, none of which are seen in the male partner.

Serum testosterone and FSH levels can also be measured in women with infertility if disorders such as polycystic ovary syndrome or diminished ovarian reserve are suspected. This female partner has regular menses, an unremarkable medical history, and no abnormalities on physical examination, so these conditions are unlikely. This couple has only been trying to conceive for 6 months, so a different step is more appropriate at this time.

C) CORRECT:

A couple should be evaluated for infertility if they are unable to conceive after ≥ 12 months of unprotected sex in women < 35 years and after ≥ 6 months in women ≥ 35 years of age. Other factors that warrant immediate evaluation of infertility include menstrual cycle abnormalities, endometriosis, history of uterine, tubal, or peritoneal disease, and suspected or known male partner infertility. This 32-year-old woman has regular menses, an unremarkable medical history, and no abnormalities on physical examination. Her husband has a history of successfully managed gonorrhea 10 years ago and shows no abnormalities on physical examination. They both appear to be healthy and have only been trying to conceive for 6 months, so they do not meet the criteria for infertility evaluation. At this time, the couple only requires reassurance and a follow-up in 6 months if the issue persists.

D) INCORRECT:

Semen analysis is the first diagnostic step in the evaluation of male infertility, which can develop in a patient with a history of gonorrhea. This patient's gonorrhea was successfully treated with ceftriaxone 10 years ago and is unlikely to be responsible for this couple's inability to conceive. Moreover, this couple has only been trying to conceive for 6 months, so a different step is more appropriate at this time.

E) INCORRECT:

Hysterosalpingography can be performed as a part of the infertility workup in women with suspected impaired tubal patency (e.g., due to endometriosis or pelvic inflammatory disease), structural uterine abnormalities (e.g., septate uterus, submucous fibroids, intrauterine adhesions), or if other diagnostic tests did not reveal any abnormalities. This woman has regular menses, an unremarkable medical history, and no findings consistent with tubal or uterine abnormalities. Moreover, this couple has only been trying to conceive for 6 months, so a different step is more appropriate at this time.

F) INCORRECT:

An antisperm antibody test can be used in male individuals with suspected infertility to detect the presence of antisperm antibodies, which are believed to develop as a result of blood-testis barrier disruption (e.g., due to testicular trauma, infection). This patient has no history of testicular trauma, and his history of gonorrhea 10 years ago is unlikely to be responsible for this couple's inability to conceive.
questions.hint: The diagnosis of infertility and the need for further workup mainly depend on the woman's age and length of time a couple of reproductive age has not been able to conceive despite having unprotected sex.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 5-day history of abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. She says that she has gained 3 kg (7 lb) over the past week despite no dietary changes. She has a history of polycystic ovary syndrome and started gonadotropin therapy for infertility 4 months ago. Ten days ago, she received an ovulatory dose of human chorionic gonadotropin. She is in moderate distress. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 86/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. The abdomen is distended and diffusely tender to palpation without rebound or guarding. Pelvic examination is unremarkable. Laboratory studies show:


Hematocrit
47%


Leukocyte count
16,000/mm3



Serum



Na+

139 mEq/L


K+

4.1 mEq/L


Cl-

102 mEq/L


Urea nitrogen
26 mg/dL


Creatinine
1.1 mg/dL


Transvaginal ultrasonography shows enlarged ovaries and free fluid in the pouch of Douglas. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Massive luteinization of the ovarian granulosa cells following ovulation induction with exogenous human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) is thought to be the cause of OHSS. The granulosa cells release a number of vasoactive mediators, most importantly vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF). VEGF increases the capillary permeability and leads to third spacing, which can manifest with enlargement of the ovaries, ascites, and weight gain. Mild to moderate OHSS, as seen here, typically develops 3–7 days after the administration of the ovulatory dose of hCG. Severe OHSS usually has a later onset and can lead to pleural effusion, acute kidney injury, thromboembolism, and sepsis.

Mild to moderate OHSS can be managed on an outpatient basis, with limited physical activity, hydration (1–2 L/day), acetaminophen, and daily monitoring of body weight and urine output. Severe OHSS requires hospitalization and a multidisciplinary management approach.

B) INCORRECT:

Ovarian cyst rupture can manifest with abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and free pelvic fluid on TVUS. However, weight gain, leukocytosis, and hemoconcentration are not typical of ovarian cyst rupture. Furthermore, the symptoms usually have a sudden onset following sexual intercourse or strenuous physical activity, and the abdominal pain is usually limited to one of the lower quadrants, which is inconsistent with this patient's 5-day history of diffuse abdominal pain. In addition, TVUS in a patient with ovarian cyst rupture is more likely to show a unilateral ovarian cyst rather than the bilateral ovarian enlargement seen here.

C) INCORRECT:

Ovarian pedicle torsion (i.e., ovarian torsion) can manifest with abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and free pelvic fluid on TVUS. However, weight gain, leukocytosis, and hemoconcentration are not typical symptoms. Furthermore, TVUS typically shows a unilateral adnexal mass, which is inconsistent with the bilateral ovarian enlargement seen here. Although ovarian enlargement increases the risk of developing ovarian torsion, this patient's clinical findings are inconsistent with this diagnosis.
Image Description:

In ovarian torsion, the ovary twists around the adnexal ligaments, resulting in compression of the ovarian veins and lymphatics, consequently causing venous congestion and edema. The most important risk factor is ovarian enlargement, which can occur (e.g., due to ovarian cysts).

D) INCORRECT:

Extrauterine oocyst implantation leads to ectopic pregnancy, which can also manifest with abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and free pelvic fluid on TVUS. Women receiving infertility treatment are at an increased risk for ectopic pregnancy. However, leukocytosis and hemoconcentration are not expected in ectopic pregnancy and TVUS usually shows a unilateral adnexal mass rather than the bilateral ovarian enlargement seen here. Moreover, most individuals develop symptoms at least 6 weeks after their last menstrual period; this woman received an ovulatory dose of hCG only 10 days ago.
Image Description:

Ultrasound pelvis (transabdominal; transverse plane) of a 31-year-old woman with history of abdominal pain, presyncope, and a positive pregnancy test

A thick-walled echogenic ring lesion (blue overlay) is seen in the right adnexa, adjacent to which there is trace free fluid (yellow overlay). No uterine masses were identified and an intrauterine gestation was not detected. The adnexal lesion proved to represent a gestational sac of an ectopic pregnancy.

An adnexal mass separate from the ovary is a common presentation of ectopic pregnancy. The diagnosis becomes more specific if a yolk sac or living embryo is detected within the mass. Color Doppler of an ectopic pregnancy may show prominent peripheral vascularity (ring of fire sign), which can similarly occur with a corpus luteum cyst.

Green overlay: uterine wall
Red overlay: endometrial stripe
IIA: internal iliac artery
IIV: internal illiac vein
O: ovary

E) INCORRECT:

Bacterial infection (e.g., with Chlamydia trachomatis or Neisseria gonorrhoeae) can lead to pelvic inflammatory disease (PID). PID can manifest with abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, leukocytosis, enlarged adnexa, and free pelvic fluid on TVUS. However, weight gain is not expected in PID. Furthermore, this patient does not have other common symptoms of PID, such as fever, urinary symptoms, vaginal discharge, and cervical motion tenderness.
questions.hint: In a patient receiving exogenous gonadotropin, abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and weight gain in combination with leukocytosis, hemoconcentration, enlarged ovaries, and free pelvic fluid on transvaginal ultrasound (TVUS) suggest ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS), a potentially life-threatening complication of infertility therapy.

questions.text:
A previously healthy 40-year-old woman reports vomiting, dyspnea, and progressive abdominal distention for the past 2 days. She has never been pregnant, although she and her husband of 3 years have been sexually active throughout their marriage. Eight days earlier, as part of an in vitro fertilization protocol, she was treated with follicle-stimulating hormone, gonadotropin-releasing hormone, and human chorionic gonadotropin — and underwent the transfer of two embryos.
Physical examination reveals a temperature of 36.4°C, a blood pressure of 110/60 mm Hg, a heart rate of 110 beats per minute, and a respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute. Cardiac examination is normal. Breath sounds are absent in the lower third of her thorax bilaterally, with dullness to percussion and absent fremitus. She has abdominal distention with a palpable fluid wave, but no rashes. Bilateral lower-extremity edema to the knee is evident.
Laboratory findings include hematocrit of 48% (reference range, 36–46), normal leukocyte and platelet counts, normal liver-enzyme levels, and a normal serum creatinine level.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Thrombotic microangiopathy can occur in pregnancy but would usually result in anemia and elevated liver-enzyme levels.

B) CORRECT:

Acute-onset bilateral pleural effusions — accompanied by ascites, peripheral edema, and hemoconcentration — are relatively rare in women of childbearing age. Those findings, plus a history of recent exogenous ovarian stimulation, are sufficient to make the clinical diagnosis of ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS).

The principal pathophysiologic process of OHSS is increased capillary permeability, caused by heightened release of vasoactive mediators from the maturation of multiple ovarian follicles. Vascular endothelial growth factor is one of the potential mediators. The increased capillary permeability results in pleural effusions (usually bilateral), ascites, peripheral edema, and hemoconcentration. In severe cases (about 0.5% to 5% of patients undergoing exogenous ovarian stimulation), pericardial effusion, hyperkalemia, and hypovolemic shock can occur. Supportive medical therapy is usually sufficient for OHSS, as it is a self-limited condition.

Key learning point: Acute-onset third spacing of fluid (pleural effusions, ascites, peripheral edema) in the setting of recent exogenous ovarian stimulation is most consistent with a diagnosis of ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome.

C) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary embolism, which can occur as a complication of OHSS, rarely causes bilateral pleural effusions and would not be associated with ascites.

D) INCORRECT:

Hyperemesis gravidarum is unlikely to cause pleural effusions.

E) INCORRECT:

Graves disease is unlikely to cause pleural effusions.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman is unable to conceive despite having regular intercourse with her male partner without contraception for the past year. She has never been pregnant and has had irregular periods (as infrequently as three times a year) for the past 5 years. Her partner fathered three children in a previous marriage without difficulty.
Laboratory testing on day 3 of her menstrual cycle reveals a follicle-stimulating hormone level of 16 mIU/mL (reference range, 3–20) and an antimüllerian hormone level of 0.1 ng/mL (>0.5 indicates good ovarian reserve).
Which one of the following next steps is best for addressing this couple’s infertility?

choices.text: Order MRI of the pituitary gland
Refer for initiation of fertility treatment

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The clomiphene citrate challenge test is used to establish the response and functionality of the ovaries. In this case, it would not provide any additional information.

B) INCORRECT:

MRI of the pituitary gland is unlikely to be helpful in a patient with normal to elevated gonadotropin levels. Infertility associated with pituitary disease is associated with low levels of gonadotropins.

C) CORRECT:

Normally, an accelerated rate of follicular atresia is observed in women age 35 and older. The most commonly used test to assess ovarian reserve is a day-3 follicle-stimulating hormone level, which is expected to be below 10 mIU/mL in women with reproductive potential; levels of 10 to 20 mIU/mL are associated with both poor ovarian stimulation and failure to conceive, with higher levels in and above this range indicating increasingly poor ovarian reserve. Antimüllerian hormone can be measured at any stage of the menstrual cycle. Serum antimüllerian hormone levels above 0.5 ng/mL are consistent with good ovarian reserve, whereas lower levels suggest depletion of the ovarian follicle pool. Levels below 0.15 ng/mL suggest that the patient will respond poorly to in vitro fertilization.

A 35-year-old woman with primary infertility, oligomenorrhea, and diminished ovarian reserve has a poor prognosis for spontaneous conception; prompt referral to a fertility specialist for infertility treatment is most appropriate.

Key learning point: Tests that can usefully indicate poor ovarian reserve in a 35-year-old woman with infertility are measurement of follicle-stimulating hormone on day 3 of the menstrual cycle and antimüllerian hormone at any stage of the menstrual cycle.

D) INCORRECT:

Endometrial biopsy is used to assess the maturity of the endometrium. It has poor prognostic value for ovulation detection and endometrial receptivity.

E) INCORRECT:

Measurement of inhibin B is not indicated or necessary for a patient whose testing already indicated diminished ovarian reserve.

questions.text:
A 31-year-old woman describes 3 days of abdominal discomfort, bloating, and nausea, with an apparent weight gain of 2.3 kg. She has a history of polycystic ovary syndrome and infertility and is taking gonadotropins for ovulation induction. Her last menstrual period was 7 days ago.
The patient has normal vital signs. Physical examination reveals a slightly distended, diffusely tender abdomen with no other abnormalities. Laboratory findings are as follows: beta human chorionic gonadotropin <5 mIU/mL (reference range, <5), hemoglobin 18.0 g/dL (12.0–16.0), and hematocrit 49.0% (36.0–46.0).
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome is a known complication of assisted reproductive treatment, particularly when ovulation induction agents, such as gonadotropins, are used. It is thought to be attributable to the high estrogen levels that can develop following treatment with fertility drugs. Women with polycystic ovary syndrome who are treated with gonadotropins for infertility are at especially increased risk for this syndrome. Signs and symptoms include abdominal discomfort, bloating, gastrointestinal disturbances, evidence of large ovaries on ultrasound, ascites, and hemoconcentration.

Key learning point: In a woman with polycystic ovary syndrome who develops abdominal pain and hemoconcentration with a negative pregnancy test during treatment with gonadotropins for infertility, the most likely diagnosis is ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

Ectopic pregnancy is very unlikely in a patient with a negative pregnancy test.

C) INCORRECT:

Struma ovarii refers to the presence of an ovarian teratoma that is predominantly composed of mature thyroid tissue. It typically manifests in a fashion similar to other ovarian tumors, with pelvic pain and a palpable abdominal mass; less commonly, it can be associated with ascites and clinical manifestations of hyperthyroidism.

D) INCORRECT:

Ovarian torsion can be a complication of ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome and enlarged ovaries. It typically causes acute lower abdominal pain that is localized to one side, often with signs of peritoneal irritation. Ovarian torsion does not typically lead to hemoconcentration.

E) INCORRECT:

Diabetes insipidus can cause hemoconcentration but is characterized by excessive thirst and urination, leading to dehydration and weight loss.

questions.text:
A 33-year-old woman reports that she and her husband have failed to conceive despite regular intercourse for the past 2 years. Neither of them have previously had any children.
The patient says that her husband has never had chemotherapy, past testicular trauma, or symptoms to suggest hypogonadism; his semen analysis is within normal limits.
The patient states that her menstrual periods are always regular, coming every 28 to 30 days and lasting 3 to 5 days. She has no known medical problems and has been trying to follow what she calls a “healthy lifestyle” that includes regular exercise and a healthful diet.
A gynecologic examination is normal, including secondary sexual characteristics. Her BMI is 26.
In addition to a hysterosalpingogram, which one of the following diagnostic tests is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Testing for antisperm antibodies is reserved for refractory and apparently idiopathic infertility.

B) INCORRECT:

Thyroid-stimulating hormone and prolactin levels are unlikely to be abnormal in a woman with normal menses.

C) CORRECT:

Approximately 40% of infertility cases are caused by female factors, approximately 30% are caused by male factors, and about 30% are idiopathic. Although it is customary to start the diagnostic process with the female partner, the laboratory workup begins with a semen analysis in the male partner. The early steps in an infertility evaluation include hysterosalpingogram to assess the shape and any pathology of the uterine cavity and to evaluate the patency of the fallopian tubes.

The most commonly used test to assess ovarian reserve is a day-3 follicle-stimulating hormone level, which is expected to be below 10 mIU/mL in women with reproductive potential; levels of 10 to 20 mIU/mL are associated with both poor ovarian stimulation and failure to conceive. The antimüllerian hormone level is a similar biochemical measure of ovarian reserve and can be measured at any stage of the menstrual cycle.

Key learning point: The most appropriate test to determine ovarian reserve for a woman with primary infertility is to measure the level of follicle-stimulating hormone on day 3 or antimüllerian hormone at any stage of the menstrual cycle.

D) INCORRECT:

The postcoital test is no longer considered a valid method for evaluation of cervical factors and should not be included in the evaluation of infertile couples.

E) INCORRECT:

Karyotyping is usually performed when a severe male infertility factor such as aspermia or oligospermia is identified.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman with a history of polycystic ovary syndrome reports that her menses last 2 weeks or more and occur every 3 to 4 months. She has been unable to become pregnant despite 2 years of regular intercourse with her husband without contraception. She is otherwise healthy. Her husband fathered two children in a previous marriage.
Her gynecologic examination is entirely normal, including secondary sexual characteristics. She has mild acne and hirsutism. Her BMI is 28.
What is the first-line approach to managing this patient's anovulation and infertility?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) is often accompanied by infertility and metabolic syndrome.

Historically, clomiphene (a selective estrogen-receptor modulator) has been used for ovulation induction in patients with PCOS. It antagonizes hypothalamic estrogen receptors to increase secretion of endogenous gonadotropins, resulting in ovarian stimulation and ovulation. Clomiphene is approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) for this indication and has been shown to be superior to metformin alone to achieve pregnancy with a low rate of multiple births. The combination of clomiphene with an insulin-sensitizing agent (such as metformin) is not clearly superior to clomiphene alone.

Letrozole is an aromatase inhibitor that blocks estrogen synthesis; the reduced estrogen lowers negative feedback and enhances hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian function, resulting in ovulation induction. Letrozole is not FDA-approved for ovulation induction but has been used off-label for this indication for years and is now the preferred first-line treatment for anovulatory infertility in PCOS. A large, double-blind, randomized controlled trial published in 2014 showed that women with PCOS who took letrozole for ovulation induction had a significantly higher live-birth rate than those who took clomiphene (27.5% vs. 19.1%) and also a significantly higher cumulative ovulation rate (61.7% vs 48.3%).

Key learning point: In an anovulatory patient with polycystic ovary syndrome, the first-line medical approach to the treatment of infertility is letrozole.

B) INCORRECT:

If a patient does not become pregnant with initial medical management, additional options such as recombinant gonadotropins and ovarian drilling are appropriate to consider. Synthetic gonadotropins must be used cautiously because patients with polycystic ovary syndrome are more prone to ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome.

C) INCORRECT:

Although metformin addresses associated metabolic disease in patients with polycystic ovary syndrome, it has been shown to be inferior to other oral ovulation-induction agents when used alone.

D) INCORRECT:

Intrauterine insemination is used to introduce sperm into the uterine cavity. It is reserved for idiopathic cases of infertility and for cases caused by a cervical etiology or poor sperm count and quality.

E) INCORRECT:

If a patient does not become pregnant with initial medical management, additional options such as recombinant gonadotropins and ovarian drilling are appropriate to consider.

questions.text: In which one of the following couples would additional evaluation for infertility typically be recommended?

choices.text: 25-year-old man and 35-year-old woman with no pregnancy after 4 months of intercourse without contraception
34-year-old man and 36-year-old woman with no pregnancy after 6 months of intercourse without contraception
35-year-old man and 29-year-old woman with no pregnancy after 8 months of intercourse without contraception
49-year-old man and 26-year-old woman with no pregnancy after 6 months of intercourse without contraception
25-year-old man and 23-year-old woman with no pregnancy after 7 months of intercourse without contraception

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Approximately 10% of couples have difficulty conceiving. There are many possible causes, and an evaluation for contributors to infertility is therefore needed. Typically, this is done after 12 months of regular intercourse without contraception. However, if the female partner is ≥35 years old, the evaluation is started after 6 months of regular intercourse without contraception; delaying diagnosis and treatment may worsen the couple’s chances of a successful pregnancy, given the rapid age-related decline in fertility at this age.

B) CORRECT:

Approximately 10% of couples have difficulty conceiving. There are many possible causes, and an evaluation for contributors to infertility is therefore needed. Typically, this is done after 12 months of regular intercourse without contraception. However, if the female partner is ≥35 years old, the evaluation is started after 6 months of regular intercourse without contraception; delaying diagnosis and treatment may worsen the couple’s chances of a successful pregnancy, given the rapid age-related decline in fertility at this age.

Workup for infertility involves identifying the etiology (male factors, female factors, or both). Approximately 40% of infertility cases are caused by female factors, approximately 30% are caused by male factors, and about 30% are idiopathic. In the male partner, laboratory workup begins with a semen analysis. In the female partner, early steps in evaluation include hysterosalpingography to assess the shape and any pathology of the uterine cavity and to evaluate the patency of the fallopian tubes. In addition, biochemical testing of ovarian reserve is usually performed, most commonly with a day-3 follicle-stimulating hormone level; the antimüllerian hormone level is a similar biochemical measure of ovarian reserve and can be measured at any stage of the menstrual cycle.

Key learning point: Couples who are unable to conceive despite regular intercourse without contraception should undergo an evaluation for infertility after one year if the female partner is <35 years old or after 6 months if she is ≥35 years old

C) INCORRECT:

Approximately 10% of couples have difficulty conceiving. There are many possible causes, and an evaluation for contributors to infertility is therefore needed. Typically, this is done after 12 months of regular intercourse without contraception. However, if the female partner is ≥35 years old, the evaluation is started after 6 months of regular intercourse without contraception; delaying diagnosis and treatment may worsen the couple’s chances of a successful pregnancy, given the rapid age-related decline in fertility at this age.

D) INCORRECT:

Approximately 10% of couples have difficulty conceiving. There are many possible causes, and an evaluation for contributors to infertility is therefore needed. Typically, this is done after 12 months of regular intercourse without contraception. However, if the female partner is ≥35 years old, the evaluation is started after 6 months of regular intercourse without contraception; delaying diagnosis and treatment may worsen the couple’s chances of a successful pregnancy, given the rapid age-related decline in fertility at this age.

E) INCORRECT:

Approximately 10% of couples have difficulty conceiving. There are many possible causes, and an evaluation for contributors to infertility is therefore needed. Typically, this is done after 12 months of regular intercourse without contraception. However, if the female partner is ≥35 years old, the evaluation is started after 6 months of regular intercourse without contraception; delaying diagnosis and treatment may worsen the couple’s chances of a successful pregnancy, given the rapid age-related decline in fertility at this age.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman reports that she has been unable to conceive for 3 years. She and her partner are sexually active and do not use contraception. They were partially assessed 6 months ago. Analysis of her husband's semen showed normal sperm counts, and hormonal assays for both partners were normal. Her menses occur at regular 28-day intervals and last 5 to 6 days. Her last menstrual period was 2 weeks ago. Vaginal examination shows no abnormalities. Bimanual examination shows a normal-sized uterus and no palpable adnexal masses. Rectal examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Psychological counseling is recommended for all couples who seek evaluation for infertility because not being able to conceive is associated with emotional stress and can lead to depression, anxiety, and feelings of worthlessness. Moreover, emotional stress may decrease libido. While this couple should receive psychological counseling, further evaluation for the cause of infertility is also necessary.

B) INCORRECT:

A postcoital test was used in the past but is no longer recommended since the results are a poor predictor of the ability to conceive and do not affect clinical management of infertility in any way.

C) INCORRECT:

Hysteroscopy is the most appropriate next step in the diagnostic evaluation of the female partner if she has risk factors for tubal obstruction, such as endometriosis, pelvic inflammatory disease, or a previous ectopic pregnancy. This patient does not have a history suggestive of any of these conditions. Hysteroscopy is therefore not indicated at this point.

D) CORRECT:

If the initial workup does not reveal any abnormalities and the patient has no history suggestive of tubal obstruction, the most appropriate next step in the evaluation of infertility is hysterosalpingography (HSG) or sonohysterosalpingography to screen for tubal occlusion and structural uterine abnormalities (e.g., septate uterus, submucous fibroids, intrauterine adhesions). In some cases, HSG can also be therapeutic because it can remove small adhesions or mucous plugs obstructing the tubal lumen. If evidence of intrauterine abnormalities or tubal occlusion is seen on HSG, hysteroscopy and/or laparoscopy should be performed next.
Image Description:

Hysterosalpingogram

The tube is occluded at the isthmic portion of the fallopian tubes on both sides (arrows). Size and shape of the uterine cavity are inconspicuous.

These findings are consistent with bilateral tubal blockage.

E) INCORRECT:

Karyotyping for chromosomal defects such as Klinefelter syndrome or Y chromosomal deletions should be performed on the male partner if semen analysis shows oligo-/azoospermia and there is evidence of hypergonadotropic hypogonadism on hormonal analysis. This patient's partner has a normal semen analysis and normal levels of testosterone. Karyotyping is also conducted if Turner syndrome is suspected, but this female patient has no signs to indicate this condition (e.g., typical physical features, amenorrhea). Karyotyping is therefore not necessary.
questions.hint: An inability to conceive after one year of regular unprotected intercourse in a woman < 35 years of age indicates infertility. This couple's preliminary assessment revealed no male factor and no hormonal disturbances.

questions.text: A 27-year-old nulligravid woman comes to the office for the evaluation of fertility. She has been unable to conceive for 1 year despite regular intercourse with her husband twice per week. Recent analysis of her husband's semen showed a normal sperm count. Two years ago, she had an episode of a febrile illness with lower abdominal pain, which resolved under treatment with a medication she cannot recall. Menses occur at regular 28-day intervals and last 4 to 5 days. Before her marriage, she used a combined oral contraceptive pill with estrogen and progesterone consistently, in addition to barrier protection inconsistently. One year ago, she stopped using the oral contraceptive pill to try and conceive. She is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 84 kg (185 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m2. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's infertility?

choices.text: Long-term use of the oral contraceptive pill

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) may present with failure to conceive due to absent or infrequent ovulation. Key features of PCOS include hyperandrogenism, ovulatory dysfunction (i.e., amenorrhea or oligomenorrhea), and obesity. Although this patient is obese (BMI 31 kg/m2), she has regular menstrual cycles and no clinical features of hyperandrogenism, such as hirsutism or acne. Therefore, it is unlikely that she has PCOS.

B) INCORRECT:

Long-term use of the oral contraceptive pill has no effect on fertility. Studies have shown that pregnancy rates following cessation of oral contraceptives, contraceptive implants, monthly contraceptive injections, copper intrauterine devices, and/or levonorgestrel intrauterine systems are similar to those reported following discontinuation of barrier methods or use of no contraceptive method.

C) INCORRECT:

Endometriosis, resulting in pelvic inflammation and uterine adhesions, is one of the most common causes of infertility in women between 20–40 years of age. However, endometriosis commonly manifests with dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, postcoital bleeding, nonspecific abdominal or pelvic pain, and is rarely asymptomatic. This patient does not have any of the clinical features associated with endometriosis, making it an unlikely cause of her infertility.

D) INCORRECT:

Primary ovarian insufficiency (POI) commonly manifests with amenorrhea or irregular menstrual cycles. This condition can also manifest with symptoms of menopause, such as vaginal dryness, hot flashes, or mood disturbances. This patient has regular menstrual cycles and does not have any symptoms of menopause, making POI an unlikely cause of her infertility.

E) CORRECT:

Infertility following PID is a result of tubal scarring (due to salpingitis) with consequent loss of ciliary action and tubal occlusion. The risk of infertility increases with the number of episodes of PID and is around 12%, 25%, and 50% after one, two, and three episodes of PID, respectively. This patient needs further testing (e.g., hysterosalpingogram) for the evaluation of her fallopian tubes and the degree of damage. She may also require either surgery or in vitro fertilization to restore fertility.

Other complications associated with PID include tuboovarian abscess, pelvic peritonitis, sepsis, Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome, and ectopic pregnancy.
Image Description:

Hysterosalpingogram

The tube is occluded at the isthmic portion of the fallopian tubes on both sides (arrows). Size and shape of the uterine cavity are inconspicuous.

These findings are consistent with bilateral tubal blockage.
questions.hint: This woman previously engaged in high-risk sexual behavior (inconsistent use of barrier protection) and had an episode of lower abdominal pain and febrile illness. This suggests an underlying diagnosis of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID).

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman and her 35-year-old husband come to the office because they have not been able to conceive since they married 8 months ago. They have been sexually active three times a week and have not used any form of contraception since their wedding. Neither partner has previously conceived a child. The woman reports having regular menses and her last menstrual period was 3 weeks ago. Physical examinations of the woman and her husband show normal secondary sexual characteristics. Bimanual pelvic examination of the woman shows a normal cervix, mobile uterus, and no palpable adnexal masses. Urine pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management at this time?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A clomiphene citrate challenge test is used to test for diminished ovarian reserve (DOR) in women with unexplained infertility. Tests for ovarian reserve can provide prognostic information in women with risk factors for DOR (e.g., family history of early menopause, age > 35 years, history of chemotherapy or pelvic radiation). Except for age > 35 years, this woman has no such risk factors, so DOR is unlikely and a clomiphene citrate challenge test is not the most appropriate test at this time.

B) INCORRECT:

Hysterosalpingography can be used to identify tubal obstruction (e.g., due to Fallopian tube adhesion) and structural uterine abnormalities (e.g., septate uterus, submucosal fibroids, intrauterine adhesions). This study should be considered in the initial workup of female infertility. However, hysterosalpingography is usually scheduled for shortly after menstrual bleeding to avoid early-pregnancy exposure to radiation. In addition, a different test is more readily available and less invasive than hysterosalpingography and therefore is the best next step for the evaluation of infertility in this couple.

C) INCORRECT:

In men, serum testosterone concentrations can be measured during the evaluation of infertility to rule out hypogonadism if there are clinical features indicative of this condition (e.g., sexual dysfunction, gynecomastia, testicular atrophy), which the man in this scenario does not have. In women, serum testosterone and other androgen concentrations may be elevated in polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), which can cause infertility. However, normal menses and the absence of hyperadrenergic manifestations in this woman make PCOS unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

This couple has been unable to conceive after > 8 months of regular unprotected sexual intercourse. In women ≥ 35 years of age, this warrants further workup of infertility. A follow-up in 4 months would be appropriate if the woman in this scenario were < 35 years of age because infertility for women < 35 years of age is defined as the inability to conceive after 12 months of regular unprotected sexual intercourse.

E) CORRECT:

Infertility is defined as the inability of a couple to conceive after regular unprotected sexual intercourse for at least 12 months in women < 35 years of age or for at least 6 months in women ≥ 35 years of age. Evaluation for infertility should be conducted concurrently in the man and the woman and should include a thorough medical history focusing on previous fertility, conditions that impact the pelvic or inguinal anatomy (e.g., history of sexually transmitted infections), medications, and systemic diseases. Semen analysis is the best initial test to evaluate for male causes of infertility (e.g., primary testicular defects of spermatogenesis) because it is fast, cost-efficient, readily available, and noninvasive. This test assesses semen pH, semen volume, and the morphology, count, and motility of the sperm cells. Abnormal results of semen analysis can guide further diagnostic tests and management (e.g., intracytoplasmic sperm injection). Hormonal analysis including TSH, prolactin, and FSH levels may also be performed to rule out endocrine and systemic disorders leading to infertility (e.g., hypothyroidism).
questions.hint: Infertility is defined in terms of the age of the female partner and the length of the period of unprotected regular sexual intercourse without conception.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man comes to the office because he and his wife have been unable to conceive despite regular unprotected sex for the past 15 months without using contraception. His wife has been tested and is fertile. The patient began puberty at the age of 14 years. He was treated for Chlamydia trachomatis 6 years ago. He is a professional cyclist and trains every day for 3–4 hours. He feels stressed because of an upcoming race. His blood pressure is 148/92 mm Hg. Physical examination of the husband shows a tall, athletic stature with uniform inflammatory papular eruptions of the face, back, and chest. Genital examination shows small testes.
